Justification: To assess for any signs of infection, anemia, or other blood-related issues that could contribute to jaundice.
To evaluate the health of the liver and check for any abnormalities in liver enzymes, bilirubin levels, and overall liver function.
To measure the levels of bilirubin in the blood, which will help determine the cause of jaundice.
To check for bilirubin and urobilinogen in the urine, which can provide additional information about liver function and possible bile duct obstruction.
To visualize the liver, gallbladder, and bile ducts to identify any structural abnormalities, obstructions, or signs of liver disease.
To test for viral hepatitis infections, which can cause liver inflammation and jaundice.
To assess the blood's ability to clot, which can be affected by liver function.
